hypotheses: Intrinsic motivation will positively moderate the BFLPE (less negative impact on self-concept); effect of extrinsic motivation is uncertain.
Self-efficacy and elaboration will positively moderate the BFLPE (higher reliance improves mathematics self-concept).
High reliance on memorization will negatively moderate the BFLPE (greater suffering in mathematics self-concept).
Use of control strategies will positively influence the BFLPE.
Individual ability may or may not moderate the BFLPE (effect may be small or nonsignificant).
Anxiety will negatively moderate the BFLPE.
Social orientations and relationships (competitive/cooperative orientation, sense of belonging, student-teacher relations) will moderate the BFLPE.
claim.hypotheses_location: Introduction / Hypotheses section (end of literature review) in the original paper
claim.statement: Students in high-ability schools develop a lower academic self-concept compared to their peers in lower-ability environments.
claim.statement_location: Abstract and Introduction of the original paper

data.source: 2003 Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) database (OECD)
data.wave_or_subset: 2003 PISA wave; 15-year-old students across 41 countries; mathematics domain; analyses used plausible values for achievement
data.sample_size: 265,180 students across 10,221 schools (after excluding students who did not complete mathematics self-concept items)
data.unit_of_analysis: Individual students nested within schools (multilevel/hierarchical structure; some models include country-level variation)
data.access_details: PISA 2003 dataset (OECD); the paper indicates PISA weights were applied but does not give specific dataset access procedures or restrictions
data.notes: Single-wave cross-sectional data; students missing math self-concept items were excluded; measures standardized (math self-concept standardized to M=0, SD=1); plausible values for achievement used; statistical weights applied

method.description: Cross-sectional analysis of 2003 PISA data using multilevel (hierarchical) linear models to examine the Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect (BFLPE) on mathematics self-concept and to test interaction effects (moderation) of SES and multiple academic self-regulation constructs. Measurement models (exploratory and confirmatory factor analysis) were used to define self-regulation constructs; multilevel regression models included fixed effects and random effects with student-level and school-level predictors and interactions between school-average ability and proposed moderators.
steps: Select 15-year-old student respondents from the 2003 PISA database and restrict sample to those who completed mathematics self-concept items.

Construct and/or standardize measurement scales (e.g., math self-concept standardized to mean 0, SD 1) and derive SES composite from parental occupation, education, home educational resources, and cultural possessions.
Use exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses to define academic self-regulation constructs (intrinsic/extrinsic motivation, self-efficacy, elaboration, memorization, control strategies, etc.).
Compute individual achievement measures and school-average achievement (school-average mathematics ability); use plausible values for student achievement as provided by PISA.
Apply PISA sampling weights to analyses to maintain representativeness.

Estimate multilevel linear regression models (students nested in schools, with country variation considered) including main effects and interactions between school-average ability and each moderator to test moderation of the BFLPE.
Assess statistical significance (paper used p < .001 given large sample) and compute effect sizes using Tymms' measure comparable to Cohen's d to evaluate practical significance.
Report fixed-effect coefficients, standard errors, random-effect variances, and interpret interaction terms for substantive significance.
method.models: Multilevel (hierarchical) linear regression models (three-level models referenced: individual/student, school, and country/community); fixed and random effects; interaction models testing moderation between school-average ability and proposed moderators. Measurement models (EFA/CFA) for construct validation.
method.independent_variables: Individual mathematics achievement (plausible values), school-average mathematics ability (school mean achievement), and moderator variables including SES components, intrinsic/extrinsic motivation, self-efficacy, elaboration, memorization, control strategies, anxiety, cooperative/competitive orientation, student-teacher relations, and sense of belonging.
method.control_variables: Demographic and background variables implicit in PISA weighting and modeling (paper applies PISA weights and accounts for nested structure); exact list of control covariates not exhaustively listed in the summary

results.summary: The Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect (BFLPE) was robustly observed: students in higher-ability schools reported lower mathematics self-concept than peers in lower-ability schools. Several moderators from SES and academic self-regulation constructs were statistically significant, but many effects were small in practical terms. Student-teacher relationships and sense of belonging mitigated some negative effects, whereas anxiety and reliance on memorization tended to exacerbate declines in mathematics self-concept in high-ability contexts. Intrinsic motivation, self-efficacy, and higher-level learning strategies were positively associated with math self-concept, but interactions with school-average ability were often negligible.

numerical_results.direction: negative (higher school-average ability associated with lower individual mathematics self-concept)

numerical_results.outcome_name: Intrinsic motivation association with math self-concept
Extrinsic motivation association with math self-concept

metadata.original_paper_title: Big-Fish-Little-Pond Effect: Generalizability and Moderation—Two Sides of the Same Coin
metadata.original_paper_data: PISA 2003 dataset (OECD) referenced in paper; no direct data link provided in the paper summary
